quiz.question: A software process model is a detailed, step-by-step implementation guide for a specific project.
quiz.suggestion: Review the definition of a software process model as an abstract representation.

quiz.question: All software processes involve the activities of specification, design and implementation, validation, and evolution.
quiz.suggestion: Refer to the four fundamental activities common to all software processes.

quiz.question: Process descriptions only include the sequence of activities and never include roles or pre- and post-conditions.
quiz.suggestion: Review what elements a process description may contain.

quiz.question: Plan-driven processes require that all process activities are planned in advance, while agile processes use incremental planning.
quiz.suggestion: Compare the core characteristics of plan-driven and agile processes.

quiz.question: The waterfall model is best suited for projects with highly volatile and changing requirements.
quiz.suggestion: Consider the inflexibility of the waterfall model in accommodating change.

quiz.question: Incremental development interleaves the activities of specification, development, and validation.
quiz.suggestion: Review how incremental development differs from the sequential waterfall model.

quiz.question: A major advantage of incremental development is the high visibility of progress for management.
quiz.suggestion: Consider the stated drawbacks related to process visibility.

quiz.question: Integration and configuration is a process model based on assembling systems from existing reusable components.
quiz.suggestion: Review the definition of the integration and configuration model.

quiz.question: A key disadvantage of the reuse-oriented approach is that it often increases development costs and risks.
quiz.suggestion: Check the listed advantages of the integration and configuration model.

quiz.question: Software specification involves the activities of requirements elicitation, specification, and validation.
quiz.suggestion: Review the three main activities of requirements engineering.

quiz.question: Software design and implementation are always two completely separate and sequential phases.
quiz.suggestion: Note that design and implementation are often interleaved activities.

quiz.question: Architectural design, database design, interface design, and component selection are all key design activities.
quiz.suggestion: Review the list of design activities within the software design process.

quiz.question: Verification answers the question 'Are we building the right system?'
quiz.suggestion: Distinguish between the definitions of verification and validation.

quiz.question: System testing involves testing the integrated system as a whole, focusing on emergent properties.
quiz.suggestion: Review the purpose and focus of system testing.

quiz.question: The V-model of testing is primarily associated with agile development processes.
quiz.section: Testing phases in a plan-driven software process (V-model)
quiz.suggestion: Note that the V-model is linked to plan-driven, waterfall-like processes.

quiz.question: Software evolution is the process of changing software after delivery to correct faults or improve performance.
quiz.suggestion: Review the definition and purpose of software evolution.

quiz.question: Change anticipation aims to make the software process resistant to any changes in requirements.
quiz.suggestion: Understand that change anticipation involves preparing for possible changes, not resisting them.

quiz.question: System prototyping can be used to help elicit and validate requirements.
quiz.suggestion: Review the various uses of a prototype in the software process.

quiz.question: A throw-away prototype is intended to be refined into the final production system.
quiz.suggestion: Understand the fundamental purpose of a throw-away prototype.

quiz.question: Incremental delivery involves deploying completed parts of the system for end-user use and feedback.
quiz.suggestion: Review the definition and goal of incremental delivery.

quiz.question: A key problem with incremental delivery is that it eliminates the risk of overall project failure.
quiz.suggestion: Consider the challenges, not just the advantages, of incremental delivery.

quiz.question: Process improvement activities include process measurement, analysis, and change.
quiz.suggestion: Review the cyclical activities involved in process improvement.

quiz.question: The SEI Capability Maturity Model's 'Initial' level is characterized by well-defined and optimized processes.
quiz.section: The (Software Engineering Institute) SEI capability maturity model
quiz.suggestion: Review the description of the 'Initial' maturity level.

quiz.question: The agile approach to process improvement focuses on iterative development and reducing process overheads.
quiz.suggestion: Review the characteristics of the agile approach to improvement.

quiz.question: Process metrics can include the time taken, resources required, and number of defects discovered.
quiz.suggestion: Review the examples of common process metrics.

quiz.question: In the waterfall model, it is easy to go back and modify a phase once it is completed.
quiz.suggestion: Consider the sequential and phase-locked nature of the classic waterfall model.

quiz.question: The primary goal of process improvement is always to accelerate development, regardless of quality or cost.
quiz.suggestion: Review the multiple objectives of process improvement (quality, cost, time).

quiz.question: Component testing is also known as unit testing and focuses on testing individual parts of the system in isolation.
quiz.suggestion: Review the definition and scope of component/unit testing.

quiz.question: The 'Optimizing' level in the SEI CMM is the lowest level, indicating an ad-hoc and chaotic process.
quiz.suggestion: Review the hierarchy of the SEI CMM maturity levels.

quiz.question: Evolutionary prototyping involves building a prototype that is intended to be evolved into the final system.
quiz.section: Difference Between Evolutionary Prototyping and Throw-away Prototyping
quiz.suggestion: Distinguish between evolutionary and throw-away prototyping strategies.

quiz.question: A key benefit of prototyping is that it ensures the final system will have perfect error handling and recovery.
quiz.suggestion: Consider what aspects a prototype typically focuses on and what it may omit.

quiz.question: In integration and configuration, 'requirements refinement' occurs after the application system is configured.
quiz.suggestion: Review the typical sequence of stages in the integration and configuration model.

quiz.question: Process change is the final, one-time activity in the process improvement cycle.
quiz.suggestion: Understand that process improvement is a continuous, cyclical activity.

quiz.question: Debugging is the process of executing a program with test cases to find faults.
quiz.suggestion: Distinguish between the activities of testing (finding faults) and debugging (correcting faults).

quiz.question: The 'Defined' level in the SEI CMM focuses on organizational standardization and deployment of processes.
quiz.suggestion: Review the characteristics of the 'Defined' maturity level.
